title: Three people fall into Walsall Canal thinking weeds are grass
text:
Three people fell in the same canal in one evening after mistaking water weeds for a grass lawn.

A 19-year-old man plunged into the icy Walsall Canal on October 5 after mistaking overgrown algae for a path.

Minutes later Steve Worthington, 41, and his son Lewis, 11, also found themselves underwater after confusing the algae for grass.

The Canal & Rivers Trust, the charity entrusted with caring for Britain's waterways, says it is an 'ongoing battle' to clear the weeds and they have put signs up in a bid to avoid further accidents.

Three people fell in the Walsall Canal in one evening after mistaking water weeds for a grass lawn

The 19-year-old had just enjoyed a meal at Nando's in Walsall when he stepped straight into the water, panicking because he is unable to swim.

He was thankfully pulled out by friends, with the help of a passer by, and made his way to a nearby Premier Inn where hotel staff gave him towels so he could dry himself off before heading home.

Steve Worthington, 41, and his son Lewis, 11, (pictured together) found themselves underwater after confusing the algae for grass

His mother, who wished to remain anonymous, said the incident, which happened at around 7.30pm on October 4, had left her son 'traumatised'.

She added: 'My son was with his friends and saw what looked like a grass path, so walked on it and just fell in. He said he was in there for about 20 seconds.

'He saw what looked like a tyre at the bottom so he put his foot on that to push him up a bit.

Luckily his two friends and a passer by pulled him out, my son can't swim.' The mother-of-two, who lives in Darlaston, said when her son was 'soaked' when he arrived home.

She continued: 'I thought he was joking when he first told me. It gave him such a shock, it has left us all feeling shocked about what happened.

'This could happen to anyone, something needs to be done – or are they waiting for someone to fall in and die. I just thank God he came out with the help of friends and a passer by. It's horrible thinking about what could have happened.'

The teen's fall would have happened a matter of minutes before Steve Worthington and his 11-year-old son, Lewis, stepped straight into the water – also believing the weeds were grass .

The 41-year-old had to battle to keep his lad's head above the water as they desperately tried to clamber to safety. 'We just stepped straight in and went straight under the water,' he said.

'We have never been down there and we couldn't see any warning signs in place. The whole area is thick green weeds – it looks just like grass.

A 19-year-old man plunged into the icy Walsall Canal on October 5 after enjoying a meal at Nando's nearby and mistaking overgrown algae for a path

A spokesman for the Canal & River Trust, which oversees the waterway near to the site, said: 'We are aware that there is a problem with an overgrowth of weed in the basin, which can make it seem as though the area is covered in thick grass, hiding the water underneath.

'Safety signs have been installed at the basin warning people of the danger.

'Removing the weed is an ongoing battle and there will be a team from Canal & River Trust out in the basin to clear sections of the weed in the next few days.'
description: A 19-year-old man and a father and his son plunged into the icy Walsall Canal on October 5 after mistaking overgrown algae for a path.
